content.description:
At the MM Boulder, this problem is on the right hand side of the first overhang (on the right side face, not under the incline). 

  Sit start and climb the side to the top out. the side looks something like a tornado. The holds are slopey sidepulls, dips, divots, and crimpy edges.
Route starts on lower ledge by the big slab that goes down to the trail. Move around arête up into the undercling. Move left along the face until you top out in the bowl/fin.
content.protection: Need at least two to three pads (middle section puts your back straight onto rock during a fall)
content.location: Looking at the Mickey Mouse face, go to the left of the main boulder, heading towards the back side of the mickey face in between the two areas, to the second boulder formation on the left.

content.description:
At the MM Boulder, this problem is on the first overhang to the right. Sit start in the middle (the lower the hold you start on the smaller and harder it becomes). 

  Climb up and right. Also there are several eliminates to be had...

At the MM Boulder, this problem is on the first overhang to the right. Sit start in the middle (the lower the hold you start on the smaller and harder it becomes). 

  Climb up and left. Also there are several eliminates to be had...

At the MM Boulder, this problem is on the first overhang to the right. Sit start in the middle (the lower the hold you start on the smaller and harder it becomes).Climb straight up on edges and crimps---the crux move pulls up on two perfect crimps to a left hand jug. Finish on the highest point of the boulder. This problem splits the difference between the left and right variation, using holds from each problem. No doubt this line has been done before so please let me know if there is knowledge of a first ascentionist.
At the MM Boulder, this problem is on the right hand side of the first overhang (on the right side face, not under the incline). This line climbs the right side arete from the sit start.

This Climb is on Dr. Topo with a Unknown name and grade but is super fun so it deserves  to be on here. Start low on to Opposing Crimps with good left feet. The Lower right flake is off for feet. Going up right hand into a good vertical crack and 2 crimps out left for hands. Heal the top and press it out.

Start as you would for Flake Dyno SDS, on the shallow crimpy flakeish sideways crack.

 Instead of dyno-ing, climb the route using deliberate static movements. For the main dyno, use a small 3-finger left-hand crimp to pull through to the higher of the two obvious flakes.

 As far as the crux goes, it's debatable whether it's the pull-through move described above, or the topout. Both are a little committing, definitely a fun variation though!

Find the flake for the classic stand start flake on MM boulder.  Look directly underneath and you'll find a shallow crimpy flakeish sideways crack. Sit start by matching on the hold and dyno to the start of the Flake Dyno problem and finish the climb.   My opinion... adds another fun dyno to a great problem
On the left overhanging portion of the main Micky Mouse Boulder formation, Stand start on the massive flake. Make a huge dyno to the next, higher flake.

The Crux is definitely the second dyno, which is both good(because it's a sick dyno)(....and) bad because while the hold isn't going to break it's also very difficult to hit/stick.  Cool variation, though definitely ups the grade
content.location: MM boulders, start on Flake Dyno SDS, make the first dyno up to the low big flake and look for the slopey left facing pocket to the right of the FD flake.  You'll also see another left facing jug right under the top further to the right(and above) of the dyno. Simple as 1,2,3,4 Top Out

content.description: Easy moves to start out lead to a tricky transition onto a steeper face and a dynamic top out at Micky Face Right finish. Crux is figuring out where to go and saving enough juice for the end. Fun traverse!
content.location: Start all the way left on good juggy holds left of the flake dyno. Head right until you transition onto the more overhanging wall that has the Micky Face L and Micky Face R routes. The huge feet to the right of the crack are off. Keep going right and finish on Micky Face R with a dynamic move.

content.description:
This problem is on the left, smaller boulder beside the main formation. 

  Listed as a standard v6 in the Dr Topo, but I think its pretty harsh, and really sharp. I call it 6+, but feel free to disagree. MP goes with consensus. 

  Sit start at the boulder right side and traverse the boulder through heinous crimpers and bad feet to the apex of the boulder. The Topo adds that this is looked at as a pain tolerance problem.

I am using the problem descriptions from the mini Dr Topo guide that Jay Shultis put out a little while back. Thanks for all the hard work Jay! Ill add in any additional info that I know of as well.

 Micky Mouse Boulders are approx 1 mile up the fire road and the approach is easy-going. The boulders are best known for the challenging beginner level climbs. Micky left, and the flake dyno are classic lines for these boulders and are not to be missed. The Micky Mouse Boulders have everything from vertical lines to steep inclines and dynamic cruxes. Your sure to enjoy yourself here!
